courses.name: Introduction to Health: Determinants of Health & Health Care

cmCourseInfo.description: A multidisciplinary approach to understanding perspectives in health, health equity, and primary health care. Themes include critical discussion of the measurements of health outcomes and the socioeconomic and political factors that affect health, including neglected and marginalized populations in Canada and globally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health: Determinants of Health & Health Care

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include small group discussions and as well as class presentations. It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to health policy in Canada, with a particular focus on the social determinants of health, and on how to improve health through policy advocacy. Examines the policy making process in the Canadian context, and the development of health policy in Canada. Explores current debates about health issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Policy in Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. courses.name: Introduction to Research Methods in Health Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Offers students in Health Studies a basic understanding of research design and data collection on health topics. Also assesses the usefulness of research and data collection in the formation of health policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Research Methods in Health Studies

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Special Topics in Health Studies I

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Historical and Ethical Perspectives in Gender, Ethnicity and Race in Health

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Oct 2, 2020: section added.

cmCourseInfo.description: The specific content of this course will vary from one year to another, depending on the availability of particular health researchers and scholars. Specific course information will be available on the Health Studies website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies/.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be held online and will have both asynchronous and synchronous elements. For example, some lectures may be delivered asynchronously, while discussions may be held synchronously. It is recommended that students have access to a microphone and camera to participate in online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
July 20, 2020: Course moved from F to S term.
August 28, 2020: Meeting Day changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
July 20, 2020: Course moved from F to S term.
August 28, 2020: Meeting Day changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides an understanding of the interface between health and aging, and how to maintain wellness in a rapidly aging population. Examines theories of aging, the meaning of health in old age, myths about the health of Canada’s older people, and emerging national and international responses to aging populations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Aging and Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed and recorded; small group exercises and other activities will occur synchronously and asynchronously.

courses.name: Special Topics in Health Studies II (formerly UNI309H1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Nov 6, 2020: Section added.

cmCourseInfo.description: The specific content of this course will vary from one year to another, depending on the availability of particular health researchers and scholars. Specific course information will be available on the Health Studies website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies/.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Studies II (formerly UNI309H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be held online and will have both asynchronous and synchronous elements. For example, some lectures may be delivered asynchronously, while discussions may be held synchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical, in-depth exploration of contemporary health and social issues. Political, social and economic forces at play in Canadian society are examined in relation to specific health issues and policies, in order to understand general societal and system dynamics of evolution and change, and to identify implications for reform efforts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Health Policy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and available for students to watch on their own time. The synchronous class meetings will be used for learning exercises, as well as class and small group discussions that will apply and extend the materials from the lectures. It is recommended that students have access to a computer or phone with working microphone to participate in synchronous activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Extends students´ understanding of population-based strategies of health promotion in Canada. Topics include: variations in health status as affected by population patterns, class, gender, ethnicity, employment, and family composition; major causes of morbidity and mortality; the concept of "community health", opportunities and constraints facing public policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Population Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class sessions will occur online, and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include small group discussions and as well as class presentations. It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials.

cmCourseInfo.description: For students enrolled in the Health Studies Specialist and Major programs. Students engage in activities that will prepare them for independent research and practicum projects. Includes, but not limited to, sessions on topic selection and program development, finding a supervisor, ethics and professionalism, formulating a grant proposal.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Research & Practice

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours.  The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include workshops, small group discussions, and class presentations.  It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Dec 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Individual field placement with a health-related institution or organization, in which the student applies theory and skills to specific projects and/or tasks. Culminates in an oral and written report. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Studies Practicum
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HST350H1/HST350Y1 or permission of the Director

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For 'E' indicator courses: College approval is required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC173, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca. For more information and for the application form is available on the Health Studies website at: https://www.uc.utoronto.ca/health-studies

Delivery Instructions

Experiential learning component of the course may be online, requiring access to the internet, a microphone and webcam, and video-conferencing applications, otherwise it must be organized to accommodate physical distancing. In-class components will occur online (or in person if/when possible) per the meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: Over the past decades, economic globalization, widening socio-economic inequities, conflict, natural disasters, environmental degradation, and, more recently, climate change have combined to become increasingly significant forces shaping global migration fluxes. This course analyzes the impact of migration on the health of those who move and of individuals, communities and entire societies in countries of origin, transit, arrival, and resettlement. It adopts an interdisciplinary approach, incorporating scholarly work from the fields of public health, the social sciences, law, and human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Migration and Health
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HST307H1 (Special Topics in Health Studies I: Globalization, Migration and Health), offered in Winter 2017, Winter 2018, and Winter 2019

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Case Studies in Health Policy (formerly UNI408H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Analyses the formation and implementation of health policy through the use of case studies. Each case deals with a substantive health policy issue. Using case studies, students will learn to understand and analyze the processes by which public policies are formed, and perform comparisons of policy alternatives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies in Health Policy (formerly UNI408H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class sessions will occur online and students are highly encouraged to engage in these live sessions during scheduled class hours. The online class time will be used to present, discuss and critique various materials. These will include small group discussions and as well as class presentations. It is expected that students have, at minimum, audio access and, preferably, video access to properly engage in the synchronous discussions and presentations of materials.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical examination of drug development, including the role of health professionals and the pharmaceutical industry in researching, testing, marketing, licensing, and evaluating pharmaceutical drugs. Topics include the differing needs for drug development, evaluation and dispensing in lower income countries, and potential conflicts of interest in drug development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health & Pharmaceuticals
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: UNI440H1, UNI330H1 (Health & Pharmaceuticals) taken prior to 2010-11

cmCourseInfo.description: Final culminating project for students in the Health Studies Specialist. Students will prepare an undergraduate thesis by the end of the course under the supervision of a University of Toronto faculty member. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Undergraduate Health Research Project

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For 'E' indicator courses: College approval is required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC173, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca. For more information and for the application form is available on the Health Studies website at: https://www.uc.utoronto.ca/health-studies Progress, Final, and Evaluation reports are available on the Health Studies website. All reports are due as indicated on the proposal and emailed to the Director at: healthstudies.director@utoronto.ca and the Academic Liaison at: khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Independent study - one-on-one meetings will occur with supervisor online or in person as required

cmCourseInfo.description: This two-semester course designation will permit students to gain academic credit for health studies pursued independently, or to participate in an ongoing health research project, under the supervision of a University of Toronto faculty member. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Health Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the historical, ideological, economic, political, and organizational factors that shape the theory and practice of international health (IH). Students will be encouraged to critically examine some of the central tensions embedded in this field.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Nature of International Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
